title: 107_hr2645
content: The Motor Donor Act, also known as the National Organ Donor Registry, amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national organ donor registry. The subpart aims to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, improve information on donation, ensure accurate information on individual wishes, and provide grants to states for donor registries. The subpart establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry called the Registry, containing information on individuals who wish to be donors, including personal details and a unique identification number. During the initial 2-year and 4-year periods after the Motor Donor Act's enactment, the Secretary will coordinate with States and organ procurement organizations to share data and provide links between the Registry and State agencies. The Motor Donor Act aims to coordinate with States and organ procurement organizations to establish organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations will have 24-hour access to the Registry through a password provided by the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary is required to create a website within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Motor Donor Act requires the dissemination of a pamphlet to US citizens with tax returns, providing information on organ donation and a Registry website. Participation in the Registry does not impact organ allocation. The Motor Donor Act establishes a Registry for individuals to express intent for organ donation. Participation in the Registry is not legally binding consent, and individuals can cancel their participation at any time. The Secretary must inform individuals of their right to cancel and the procedure for doing so. The Secretary can remove individuals from the Registry if they cancel participation. Grants are available for States to establish State registries linked to the motor vehicle driver's license application process. States must submit applications to the Secretary to be eligible for grants. Each state must establish procedures for individuals to make legally binding organ and tissue donation gifts when applying for a driver's license. These procedures must comply with specific requirements outlined by the Secretary. State driver's license applications must include an option for individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor. The application should contain a question asking if the individual wishes to have their donor designation in the State registry. State procedures require affirmative responses on driver's license applications to note organ donor preference in the State registry or on the license. Information of affirmative responders is forwarded to the Registry. State procedures mandate that information on organ donor designation must be submitted within 100 days of designation, including any changes in designation or address. Individuals who choose not to have their organ donor designation included will not have their information forwarded to the Registry. Access to this information by organ procurement organizations is also outlined in the State procedures. The Secretary gives priority in awarding grants to States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Donor information is recorded in individual computer records and accessible 24/7 to organ procurement organizations without any fees. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ or tissue donations and procurement. No grant awarded to any State shall exceed $300,000. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ or tissue donations, procurement, and transplants. Members serve a 3-year term and may be reappointed. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary for 3-year terms. Two initial members' terms expire after 2 years. Vacancies do not affect the Task Force's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign and must submit a report within 1 year. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, must conduct a study and submit a report with recommendations for improving the Registry and increasing public awareness about organ and tissue donation. Task Force members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of its members. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. The Task Force appointed by the Secretary can accept voluntary services from members. Federal employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. The Department of Health and Human Services will provide administrative support. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Authorization of $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006, with funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. Subpart 2--Organ Procurement. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information to the Department of Health and Human Services for organ donor program purposes. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
